entry.title: 日本創業之初
entry.summary: 許多人喜歡到日本旅遊，對台灣人而言，到訪日本旅遊的頻率可能是一年一次、一年兩次或更多次，但你曾想過到日本居住嗎？ 我很喜歡日本，常在忙碌工作之餘安排時間到日本看櫻花、賞楓，但假期時間總是短短的幾天，每次到日本自由行的行程也非常緊湊、想要踏訪各個景點，所以總是裝載著許多回憶和疲憊從日本回台。 曾幻想過要到日本居住而不只是旅遊，悠閒的享受及體驗當地生活、感受四季分明的變化等，但在現實生活中幾乎是個「夢想或是幻想」，沒想到在2022年、全球疫情仍未完全平息之前，我真的能搬到日本居住。 到日本居住三個月以上的方式，可能有到日本工作、嫁(娶)日本人。如果你還年輕、有點存款，也許可以到日本語言學校就讀，除了增進語言能力外，之後也能考慮在日本找一份工作，這是一個不錯職涯的體驗，且能體驗長期住在日本的生活；又或者，在就讀語言學校、在日本職場工作的時候，幸運的認識生命中的另一半而結婚、之後選擇留在日本，這兩種方式似乎都滿適合年輕人的。 我已經不是年輕人了，所以我們選擇到日本創業。 到日本創業並不是一件容易的事情，先想像一下要放棄哪些好了，可能是原本穩定的工作、一間遮風避雨的房子、一台車子，還有許多實質或是抽象的東西。當想好你需要丟掉放下的東西後，就要開始思考如何在日本生活，說白話點就是「如何維生」，創業要做些什麼？能不能夠真的賺到錢？這兩項還算是自己能掌控的，而不能掌控的事情還有很多。但當體驗「很多事是自己無法掌控」這個想法後，似乎更能「感謝每一個機會與邂逅」，活得更感恩及感激。--未完待續
entry.content:
許多人喜歡到日本旅遊，對台灣人而言，到訪日本旅遊的頻率可能是一年一次、一年兩次或更多次，但你曾想過到日本居住嗎？

我很喜歡日本，常在忙碌工作之餘安排時間到日本看櫻花、賞楓，但假期時間總是短短的幾天，每次到日本自由行的行程也非常緊湊、想要踏訪各個景點，所以總是裝載著許多回憶和疲憊從日本回台。

曾幻想過要到日本居住而不只是旅遊，悠閒的享受及體驗當地生活、感受四季分明的變化等，但在現實生活中幾乎是個「夢想或是幻想」，沒想到在2022年、全球疫情仍未完全平息之前，我真的能搬到日本居住。

到日本居住三個月以上的方式，可能有到日本工作、嫁(娶)日本人。如果你還年輕、有點存款，也許可以到日本語言學校就讀，除了增進語言能力外，之後也能考慮在日本找一份工作，這是一個不錯職涯的體驗，且能體驗長期住在日本的生活；又或者，在就讀語言學校、在日本職場工作的時候，幸運的認識生命中的另一半而結婚、之後選擇留在日本，這兩種方式似乎都滿適合年輕人的。

我已經不是年輕人了，所以我們選擇到日本創業。

到日本創業並不是一件容易的事情，先想像一下要放棄哪些好了，可能是原本穩定的工作、一間遮風避雨的房子、一台車子，還有許多實質或是抽象的東西。當想好你需要丟掉放下的東西後，就要開始思考如何在日本生活，說白話點就是「如何維生」，創業要做些什麼？能不能夠真的賺到錢？這兩項還算是自己能掌控的，而不能掌控的事情還有很多。但當體驗「很多事是自己無法掌控」這個想法後，似乎更能「感謝每一個機會與邂逅」，活得更感恩及感激。--未完待續

entry.content:
Okayama Castle is a Japanese castle in the city of Okayama. In stark contrast to the white "Egret Castle" of neighboring Himeji, Okayama Castle has a black exterior, earning it the nickname Crow Castle or "castle of the black bird". (The black castle of Matsumoto in Nagano is also known as "Crow Castle", but it is karasu-jō in Japanese.) 

The entrance to Tenshukaku is on the first basement floor (B1) of Tenshukaku. After purchasing a ticket, you can take the elevator from the right passage. The way to visit Tenshukaku is to take the elevator to the top floor and then go down one level at a time.

The elevator goes up to the 6th floor, where visitors can see the surrounding area of Okayama Castle. The western side of Okayama Castle faces the "Ujinko Road" and the "Joshita" station, and the southern side of Okayama City Library and Okayama Prefectural Office.

The stairs between floors are not as narrow and steep as those of the original Tenshukaku, but rather wide and gentle, and it is easy to descend from the 6th floor to the 5th floor.

When you look out of the window at the 5th floor, you can still enjoy a good view of the building, especially the shiny "Golden shachi" with gold leaf on the roof.

The nearby Okayama Koraku-en is also a must-see!  It is one of the Three Great Gardens of Japan, along with Kenroku-en and Kairaku-en. Korakuen was built in 1700 by Ikeda Tsunamasa, lord of Okayama. The garden reached its modern form in 1863.

After being severely damaged by the bombing of the Second World War, the government restored the park to its original state according to the paintings and designs of the Edo period. It is managed as a historical and cultural asset and will be passed on to future generations.

If you are interested in the historical figures of Japan's Warring States period, you can experience the pride of the Warring States daimyo and the impact of ancient Japanese wars on the rise and fall of generations in Okayama Castle. And the relaxation of Okayama Koraku-en can also be arranged in the same day trip! After the visit, you will feel a sense of physical and mental relaxation.

entry.summary: Kasugataisha Shrine is a Shinto shrine in Nara,. It is the shrine of the Fujiwara family, established in 768 CE and rebuilt several times over the centuries. The interior is famous for its many bronze lanterns, as well as the many stone lanterns that lead…
entry.content:
Kasugataisha Shrine is a Shinto shrine in Nara,. It is the shrine of the Fujiwara family, established in 768 CE and rebuilt several times over the centuries. The interior is famous for its many bronze lanterns, as well as the many stone lanterns that lead up the shrine.

Kasugataisha Shrine is a large area and you will see many deer on the way from Nara Park. These deer are very cute and friendly, probably because tourists feed them with "Deer Senbei ".

The "Deer Senbei " are pancakes made of rice bran and flour that visitors can buy to feed the deer. The Nara Park Deer Lovers Association makes this kind of feed for visitors to buy, and the proceeds are used as a fund for the association's operation.

For the purpose of health conservation, the "Deer Senbei " are not seasoned, so they must not have much flavor, but the original fragrance of the rice bran must be very strong.

There are more than 1,000 deer in Nara Park, and the largest number of deer are females! Except for the doe that will be moved to another area in case of a car accident or impending birth, these free little guys in Nara Park are all wild! However, because these deer are wild and may attack people, it is still necessary to pay attention to safety.

"Todai-ji Temple, known for its ""Daibutsu-san,"" or Great Buddha, is a representative temple in Nara, with an imposing appearance of the largest wooden structure in the world. This is a famous temple of the Kegon sect and was founded by Roben.

Todai-ji Temple has a history of 1200 years. During the Nara period, when there were coups and rebellions, Emperor Somu wanted to use the power of Buddhism to relieve social unrest and ordered the construction of Kokubunji and Kokubuniji temples in various countries.

The south gate of Todai-ji Temple (Daikanyinji Gate) is a very imposing wooden structure.You need to buy a ticket to enter Todai-ji Temple, and once you enter, you will see the magnificent Great Buddha Hall, which was registered as a UNESCO World Heritage Site in 1998.

Todai-ji Temple is the largest wooden building in the world (47.5 meters high), built as a result of cultural exchange between the Tang Dynasty and China.

Nara City, the oldest capital of Japan and the city with the most domestic world heritage in Japan. It takes an incredible amount of speed to walk the entire World Heritage Site in one day. So it is recommended to spend 2 days, or split into several visits, to appreciate the historical traces carefully.

entry.content:
The Port of Kobe is a Japanese maritime port in Kobe, backgrounded by the Hanshin Industrial Region.Kobe is also a home port for certain cruise ships. Cruise lines that call at the port are kinds like Holland America Line and Princess Cruise Line. 

The Kobe Port Lighthouse has a unique appearance, resembling a bright red Japanese musical instrument "Taiko", which is very impressive. Standing on the 92-meter-high observation deck, you can enjoy a 360-degree view of Kobe Airport to the south and Mount Rokko to the north.

While the open view of the blue sea and blue sky is really beautiful during the day, the night is a completely different atmosphere! You can enjoy the splendid night view of Kobe!

Also, you can join luxury gourmet cruise -CONCERTO- allows you to enjoy gourmet food while appreciating Kobe’s attractive scenery at the same time. The gourmet meals include creative French course carefully prepared by our present top chef, world-renowned Kobe Beef and Japanese Teppanyaki (hot-plate grill).

From the night cruise, the scenery is glittery and eye-catching.This romantic and attractive atmosphere is the most suitable way for enjoying good food and wine with your loved ones, while appreciating Kobe’s amazing night view. For more information

When it comes to Kobe cuisine, apart from Kobe beef, Kobe pudding is also a must-try dessert! The pudding is made from eggs, dairy products and sugar, and has a simple but delicious taste.🤗

entry.content:
Himeji Castle is a hilltop Japanese castle complex situated in the city of Himeji. The castle is regarded as the finest surviving example of prototypical Japanese castle architecture,  and is frequently known as "White Heron Castle" because of its brilliant white exterior and supposed resemblance to a bird taking flight.

Himeji Castle is very large, covering an area of about 23 hectares, about five times the size of Tokyo Dome. About half of the area has been renovated as a park, and anyone can enter the park for free. The other area, centered around castle tower, requires a fee to enter the city.

Himeji Castle tour focuses on the interior of castle tower, where you can climb to the uppermost floor. There are many information about the history of Himeji Castle, and the miniature model shows the street scene in the past.

Himeji Castle is also a famous cherry blossom viewing spot. When you come to Kansai during the cherry blossom season, Himeji Castle is definitely not to be missed.

entry.content:
Itsukushima Shrine was built on the sea, so the view varies with the tide. When the tide level is 250cm or higher, the shrine looks like it is floating on the sea. If the tide is below 100cm, you can walk around the Ootorii. If you stay in the morning and evening on a day when the tide is not as high as it should be, you can experience both “floating in the sea” and “walking under the big torii”.。👉 👉Miyajima Tourist Association

When you come to Miyajima, don’t forget to eat the local food!～❤️

Raw Oysters
Local oysters are not only fresh and juicy, but they can be eaten in a variety of ways.Raw, grilled, fried and other cooking methods are available to satisfy the taste buds of gourmets.The only thing you have to worry about is whether you can handle the freshness of the sea.

Red Leaf Buns
The outside crust is similar to the texture of honey cake, and the shape is modeled after the leaves of the prefectural maple tree in Hiroshima.The filling is available in red bean, white bean, matcha, chestnut, cream, chocolate and cheese fillings.Ahh, it’s really delicious!

entry.title: Hiroshima Peace Memorial
entry.summary: Hiroshima Peace Memorial On August 6, 1945, the U.S. Army bombed Hiroshima with an atomic bomb, and almost all of the buildings near the center of the blast were razed to the ground, except for this building, which barely stood and did not completely collapse.
entry.content:
Hiroshima Peace Memorial

On August 6, 1945, the U.S. Army bombed Hiroshima with an atomic bomb, and almost all of the buildings near the center of the blast were razed to the ground, except for this building, which barely stood and did not completely collapse. The atomic bomb dome was preserved as a memorial of the incident and is part of the Hiroshima Peace Memorial Park.

This building was first completed in 1910 as the “Hiroshima Prefectural Products Exhibition Hall” and was renamed the “Hiroshima Prefectural Products Exhibition Hall” in 1921 and the “Hiroshima Prefectural Industry Award Hall” in 1933, making it an important exhibition venue in Hiroshima at that time.

Hiroshima Peace Memorial Museum

The Hiroshima Peace Memorial Museum is the largest museum in Hiroshima City related to the atomic bombing. The museum details the tragic events of August 6, 1945, and displays artifacts left behind after the atomic bombing so that people can empathize with the victims of Hiroshima.

The power of the atomic bomb was not limited to the many people who died on the spot, but also to the many people who suffered from the effects of the blast, heat injuries, and nuclear radiation. There are many sad stories in the museum, and although I was mentally prepared before visiting the museum, I still feel very strongly after visiting the museum, which makes people cherish the days of world peace.

entry.content:

Walking on the bridge, you can enjoy a 360 degree view, but it takes courage to challenge the 390 meter long, 173 meter high, 1.5 meter wide suspension bridge, and you need to hold your phone and camera steady.However, walking on the Skywalk and watching the magnificent scenery cleanses the body and mind.❤️

Although the leaves were not all red at the time of the photo shoot, you can imagine how touching it will be when all the leaves in the valley turn red.
If you visit Oita, you must take on this suspension bridge and see this magnificent view!

entry.title: Nagasaki Bio Park
entry.summary: Nagasaki Biopark is located in Nishikai City on the west side of Nagasaki . You can get close to the animals and experience feeding them, and besides the famous “Capybaras”, which are the most healing animals, there are also many cute animals ~ and this…
entry.content:
Nagasaki Biopark is located in Nishikai City on the west side of Nagasaki . You can get close to the animals and experience feeding them, and besides the famous “Capybaras”, which are the most healing animals, there are also many cute animals ~ and this cute alpaca greeted me at the entrance.

The park is divided into 12 areas such as “Flower Dome”, “Amazon Pavilion”, “Andes Square and Camel Rock Hill”, etc. Follow the signs to enter the area where the animals are kept.

The capybaras originates from South America and belongs to the class of rats, with a dumb and helpless expression that looks super therapeutic. From the map, the capybaras lives in the top left corner (7)!

Capybaras especially like to eat “bamboo leaves”, so you can feed them here! The cute capybaras will approach as soon as they see the bamboo leaves. But when the bamboo leaves are finished, they will leave silently 😅

In addition to feeding, you can also experience gently touching them, the capybara’s fur is hard and a bit prickly 😆

When the weather is cold, the capybaras will also be near the fireplace, soak in the hot spring to warm up.

In addition to the capybaras, there are many other lovely animals that feel much more relaxed in the vast zoo.Well worth visiting with parents and children.

entry.title: Akashi Kaikyo Bridge
entry.summary: The Akashi Kaikyo Bridge is the world’s largest bridge and suspension bridge spanning the Akashi Strait, connecting Kobe City in Hyogo Prefecture with Awaji City. The Maiko Sea Trail is a trail under the Akashi Kaikyo Bridge, and is similar to the Shikoku-Woji Trail, so…
entry.content:
The Akashi Kaikyo Bridge is the world’s largest bridge and suspension bridge spanning the Akashi Strait, connecting Kobe City in Hyogo Prefecture with Awaji City.

The Maiko Sea Trail is a trail under the Akashi Kaikyo Bridge, and is similar to the Shikoku-Woji Trail, so you can experience the feeling of “walking” on the sea.

Walking along the sea trail, you can also see the Sun Moon Memorial Hall (Ijokaku) in the distance, which is built in 1915. Its iconic three-story octagonal hall creates a nostalgic atmosphere.

Finally, when you come to Akashi, you must eat Akashi-yaki, which is similar in appearance to takoyaki but made in a different way. The egg content of Akashi is higher than that of takoyaki, and the restaurant will include a kombu soup for customers to eat (soak the Akashi before eating), which is why some people call it “takoyaki with soup”; or you can spread the sauce provided by the restaurant on the Akashi and eat it directly.🤩
